reviewText: "Fleetwood Mac- Unbroken Chain" is a boring, disappointing documentary about Fleetwood Mac. While it is mildly interesting discussing the band's origins as Peter Green's Fleetwood Mac, to how one of the band members joined the Family of God--it really doesn't shed as much as light as it should. There are no interviews with Lindsey Buckingham and Stevie Nicks, who were important to the band's "California sound." There are some former bandmates, some from such groups as Chicken Shack. The love affairs between band members gets briefly dabbled in.Rumours (Deluxe Edition)is discussed as the ultimate soap opera concept album. The weirdness is that instead of interviewing band members--they interview the leaders of Fleetwood Mac's UK fan club(!!!)It's frustrating to hear people discuss the group's blues era before Christine McVie and Buckingham/Nicks, without the music being played. Since "Rumours" is talked about, it's sad that none of its songs are played. Ironically, it's easier to hear Fleetwood Mac songs on soft rock/soft pop stations than in this documentary. Another irony is that Fleetwood Mac's producer for "Rumours" and "Tusk" is also the father of a new diva of the California sound, Colbie Caillat (Coco,Breakthrough) Stevie Nicks went into an independent career of her own."Unbroken Chain" is a disappointing waste of time.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is a good general overview of the band, and for once recognizes that Fleetwood Mac did not begin in 1974 when Linsdey Buckingham and Stevie Nicks joined.It's OK for a documentary to be "unauthorized." For example, one of the best Beatles documentaries is "The Compleat Beatles" which the Beatles had nothing to do with. Sometimes, "authorized" bios are so sanitized by image-conscious bands that they have no real honesty. An unauthorized bio does not have to be approved by every band member and therefore the makers have more freedom to explore unpleasant topics.
Title: N/A

reviewText: When I first read the reviews on this dvd I was expecting an absolute atrocity of a mac bio. I was suprised because its not as bad as almost everyone has said it is. true, there are definate inaccuracies and no fleetwood mac music to be found, but there is some interesting commentary and alot of great photos. though I must admit VH1 behined the music and the classic albums dvd are both way better. All in all not essential but you could do worse.
summary: not essential, but not as horrible as some have made it sound
Title: N/A

reviewText: The better documentaries are Mick Fleetwood's DVD, "Classic Albums- Rumours" and the VH1 making of "Say You Will". They should put out some of the Mirage and Tusk tour videos that have been long out of print.They have a petition to put a video of their live and promo videos. They're halfway there.[...]
Title: N/A

reviewText: The fact that it says RIGHT ON THE COVER that this DVD isn't an "authorized" product of Fleetwood Mac, should have tipped me off. I must have either been on drugs or had 20 bucks burning a hole in my pocket when I bought this. There is NO FM music in this DVD, there are several factual inaccuracies, and there are no interviews with anyone really important ( no one closely associated with the band, just a few random people who played with them back in the sixties, and two members of the British fan club, of all things .) The few rare pictures shown of FM in concert and things were of only slight interest, and saved this from a one star rating. SAVE YOUR MONEY !!!! There are MUCH better FM DVD documentaries out there, most of them authorized, like the "Classic Albums" series that features "Rumours".
Title: N/A

reviewText: There are no redeeming qualities that I can mention about this unauthorized dvd.  No Fleetwood Mac interviews nor music or concert footage.  A few nice photos, big deal. Not worth it.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This was an interesting DVD telling the story of Fleetwood Mac from the start to where they are now. This DVD gave so much detail of who and what they are today. This DVD made me want to hear their songs again. Their songs are ageless as are they.
